source:
> **Tip**: Welcome to the Investigate a Dataset project! You will find tips in quoted sections like this to help organize your approach to your investigation. Before submitting your project, it will be a good idea to go back through your report and remove these sections to make the presentation of your work as tidy as possible. First things first, you might want to double-click this Markdown cell and change the title so that it reflects your dataset and investigation. # Project: Predict Show/No Show Medical Appointments ## Table of Contents
  • Introduction
  • Data Wrangling
  • Exploratory Data Analysis
  • Conclusions

## Introduction This dataset has information from 100k medical appointments in Brazil. I am considering 3 features age,neighbourhood,scholarship,hypertension to see the NoShow results. #### Question 1: whether or not patients show up for their appointment. #### Question 2: Whether female /male patients showed up most/not? #### Question 3: Which age patients showed up most? #### Question 4: Which Neighbourhood patients showed up most/not? #### Question 5: Whether Scholarship patients showed up most/not? #### Question 6: Whether Hypertension patients showed up most/not? #### Question 7: Whether SMSReceived patients showed up most/not?

#  set up import statements for all of the packages 

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import datetime
from time import strftime
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
%matplotlib inline

## Data Wrangling > **Tip**: In this section of the report, you will load in the data, check for cleanliness, and then trim and clean your dataset for analysis. Make sure that you document your steps carefully and justify your cleaning decisions. ### General Properties

# Load your data and print out a few lines. Perform operations to inspect data
#   types and look for instances of missing or possibly errant data.

#load data to dataframe

df_noshow=pd.read_csv("KaggleV2-May-2016.csv")
df_noshow.head()
#get the number of rows and columns
df_noshow.shape

source: #get the dataset details
df_noshow.info()
#### There are no null values
### Data Cleaning (Converting data types,dropping few columns)

# convert patientid to int
df_noshow['PatientId']=df_noshow['PatientId'].astype(int)

# convert ScheduledDay  and AppointmentDay to datetime

df_noshow['ScheduledDay']=pd.to_datetime(df_noshow['ScheduledDay']).dt.date.astype('datetime64[ns]')
df_noshow['AppointmentDay']=pd.to_datetime(df_noshow['AppointmentDay']).dt.date.astype('datetime64[ns]')

#rename the columns 

df_noshow.rename(columns={'Hipertension':'Hypertension','Handcap':'Handicap','SMS_received':'SMSReceived','No-show':'NoShow'},inplace=True)

######  Drop the patientId and AppointmentID columns as they are system generated and not useful for analysis.

#drop patientid and appointmentid

df_noshow.drop(['PatientId','AppointmentID'],axis=1,inplace=True)

#find unique values in each columns

df_noshow['Gender'].unique()
df_noshow['Scholarship'].unique()
df_noshow['Hypertension'].unique()
df_noshow['Diabetes'].unique()
df_noshow['Alcoholism'].unique()
df_noshow['Handicap'].unique()
df_noshow['SMSReceived'].unique()
###### columns from the above has 0 or 1 values.Convert  the other columns to object.

#convert the columns to object
df_noshow['Scholarship'] = df_noshow['Scholarship'].astype(object)
df_noshow['Hypertension'] = df_noshow['Hypertension'].astype(object)
df_noshow['Diabetes'] = df_noshow['Diabetes'].astype(object)
df_noshow['Alcoholism'] = df_noshow['Alcoholism'].astype(object)
df_noshow['Handicap'] = df_noshow['Handicap'].astype(object)
df_noshow['SMSReceived'] = df_noshow['SMSReceived'].astype(object)

# Get the Waiting Time in Days of the Patients.
df_noshow['Waiting_Time_days'] = df_noshow['AppointmentDay'] - df_noshow['ScheduledDay']
df_noshow['Waiting_Time_days'] = df_noshow['Waiting_Time_days'].dt.days

## Exploratory Data Analysis > **Tip**: Now that you've trimmed and cleaned your data, you're ready to move on to exploration. Compute statistics and create visualizations with the goal of addressing the research questions that you posed in the Introduction section. It is recommended that you be systematic with your approach. Look at one variable at a time, and then follow it up by looking at relationships between variables. ### Research Question 1 (Whether or not patient showed up for the appointments)

df_noshow['NoShow'].value_counts().plot(kind='bar')
plt.title('Show/NoShow Patients')
plt.xlabel('NoShow')
plt.ylabel('Number Of Patients');
#### *The above plot shows that there are more patients who showed up for the appointments.*
### Research Question 2 (Whether female /male patients showed up most/not?)

ax = sns.countplot(x=df_noshow.Gender, hue=df_noshow.NoShow, data=df_noshow)
ax.set_title("Show/NoShow for Females and Males")
x_ticks_labels=['Female', 'Male']
ax.set_xticklabels(x_ticks_labels)
plt.show()
#### *Female patients took more appointments and  showed up  for the appointment more than the male patients.*
### Research Question 3 (Which age  patients showed up  most?)

plt.figure(figsize=(16,4))
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
ax = sns.countplot(x=df_noshow.Age, hue=df_noshow.NoShow)
ax.set_title("Show/NoShow of Appointments by Age")
plt.show()
#### The above plot shows that for age 0 and 1 the noshow (Yes) is high compared to other ages.¶
### Research Question 4 (Which Neighbourhood patients showed up most/not?)

#plot by neighbourhood
plt.figure(figsize=(16,4))
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
ax = sns.countplot(x=np.sort(df_noshow.Neighbourhood), hue=df_noshow.NoShow, order=df_noshow.Neighbourhood.value_counts().index)
ax.set_title("Show/NoShow by Neighbourhood")
plt.show()
#### *The above plot shows that most of the neighbourhood patients who took the appointments showed up for the appointments.*
### Research Question 5 (Whether Scholarship patients showed up most/not?)

ax = sns.countplot(x=df_noshow.Scholarship, hue=df_noshow.NoShow, data=df_noshow)
ax.set_title("Show/NoShow for Scholarship")
x_ticks_labels=['No Scholarship', 'Scholarship']
ax.set_xticklabels(x_ticks_labels)
plt.show()

source: df_s_ratio = df_noshow.query('NoShow == "No"').groupby(['Scholarship']).count()/df_noshow.groupby(['Scholarship']).count()
df_s_ratio

#% of scholarship 
df_s_ratio = df_noshow.query('NoShow == "No"').groupby(['Scholarship']).count()/df_noshow.groupby(['Scholarship']).count()
ax = sns.barplot(x=df_s_ratio.index, y=df_s_ratio.NoShow)
ax.set_title("Show Percentage for Scholarship")
x_ticks_labels=['No Scholarship', 'Scholarship']
ax.set_xticklabels(x_ticks_labels)
plt.show()
#### *Around 80% of the people with no scholarship showed up for the appointments.Also around 76% of the people with scholarship showed up for the appointment.*
### Research Question 6 (Whether Hypertension patients showed up most/not?)

ax=sns.countplot(x=df_noshow.Hypertension,hue=df_noshow.NoShow,data=df_noshow)
ax.set_title("Show/NoShow for Hypertension")
x_ticks_labels=['No Hypertension', 'Hypertension']
ax.set_xticklabels(x_ticks_labels)
plt.show()

source: df_sms_ratio = df_noshow.query('NoShow == "No"').groupby(['SMSReceived']).count()/df_noshow.groupby(['SMSReceived']).count()
df_sms_ratio

ax=sns.barplot(x=df_sms_ratio.index,y=df_sms_ratio.NoShow)
ax.set_title("Show % for SMSReceived")
x_ticks_labels=['No SMSReceived', 'SMSReceived']
ax.set_xticklabels(x_ticks_labels)
plt.show()
#### *The above plot shows that 83% of the patients with no SMSReceived showed for the appointment and around 72% of the patients with SMSReceived also turned up for the appointments.*

## Conclusions:
1. There are more patients who showed up for the appointments irrespective of the features.
2. Female patients took more number of appointments and also showed up for the appointment more than the male patients.
3. For age 0 and 1 the noshow (Yes) is high compared to other ages.
4. Most of the neighbourhood patients who took the appointments showed up for the appointments.
5. More number of patients with No Scholarship showed up for the appointments compared to patients with scholarship patients.
6. More number of patients with hypertension showed up for the appointments compared to patients with no hypertension.
7. More Number of the patients with no SMSReceived showed for the appointment than the patients with SMSReceived.

#### *Limitations:*
1. The dataset is quite sufficient to come to a conclusion on the features to answer the patient show/noshow.

### With the features that I chose, age,scholarship,hypertension,smsreceived can be good pick to answer whether patient show/noshow for the appointments.
